oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery Interview of George Jones and Waylon Jennings - 1979-05-02
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of an interview of George Jones (musician) and Waylon Jennings (musician). The interview is hosted by Ralph Emery. The tape is the unedited recording. The tape was recorded May 02, 1979. This is the second tape of two.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: George Jones; Waylon Jennings; Ralph Emery
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Ralph Emery recaps George Jones "We Ought to be Ashamed;" additionally, Emery asks about Waylon Jennings time in Littlefield, Texas -- (01:57) Jones and Jennings reflect on the times where they had been fired -- (03:01) Jones praises Jennings while introducing "Amanda" -- (03:25) Emery, Jones, and Jennings joke about getting older, and Emery asks Jones about his radio career -- (05:51) Jennings and Jones reveal their age -- (07:20) Jennings performs a duck voice, and the engineer inquires as to the group had discussed Ford trucks -- (10:17) Jennings introduces the Ralph Emery show and Chuck Berry's "Nadine" -- (11:07) Emery praises Jennings' rendition of "(I'd be) A Legend in My Time" -- (12:54) Emery asks Jennings about his role for the Dukes of Hazzard -- (17:08) Jones in asked to introduce Jessi Colter -- (17:58) Emery inquires about Jennings' marriage to Colter -- (18:32) Jennings reflects on "Are You Sure Hank Done it This Way" -- (19:30) Emery introduces Jones to reflect on meeting Hank Williams -- (23:09) Jennings recalls meeting Crystal Gayle in Europe -- (23:51) Emery inquires about Jennings' nicknames -- (25:22) Jennings and Jones perform the hosting duties, and Emery asks about the other nicknames Jones and Jennings have -- (26:55) Jones performs the normal interview questions to Emery -- (28:17) Emery asks Jones to introduce "Wind Up About," and asks Jennings about his radio career and Jennings' worst record -- (33:52) Jennings praises Johnny Rodriguez and jokes about the Alamo -- (34:39) Jennings reveals he recorded Jones' "Ragged but I'm Right" -- (36:05) "Ramblin' Man" is discussed to be an odd track for Jennings, and all three joke about Merle Haggard -- (38:47) Jones reveals he wishes to discuss Emery, and Emery asks about Jones' rock career -- (40:28) Jones discusses how he would meet with an executive to discuss what country music is -- (41:31) Emery attempts to recite Jones' titles, and Jones, Jennings, and Emery discuss if Jennings is on drugs -- (44:27) Jennings and Jones show their appreciation for Emery for allowing them to be sincere
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Jones, George; Jones, George, 1931-2013; Jennings, Waylon; Emery, Ralph;
